test_cases.prompt: Question: How did the proportion of full-time employed residents who usually worked over 48 hours a week change in 2022 compared to 2010?
test_cases.expected_output: The proportion of full-time employed residents who usually worked over 48 hours a week has been on a downward trend since 2010 and this continued in 2022.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Which sectors saw a larger increase in the proportion of employees who changed their job in the last one year?
test_cases.expected_output: Sectors with a stronger demand for workers, such as Information & Communications, Financial & Insurance Services, Professional Services, and Health & Social Services, as well as tourism-related sectors such as Accommodation and Arts, Entertainment & Recreation, saw a larger increase in the proportion of employees who changed their job in the last one year. (Chart 40)

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the reason for the increase in the share of unemployed non-PMETs aged 30 to 39 who left their last job due to low pay, poor career prospects, or to provide care for their household or families?
test_cases.expected_output: According to the text, the increase was due to an increase in the share of unemployed non-PMETs aged 30 to 39 who left their last job due to low pay, poor career prospects, or to provide care for their household or families.

test_cases.prompt: Question: How many residents in Singapore did own account work as a regular form of employment over the one-year period from July 2021 to June 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: There were 257,300 residents who did own account work as a regular form of employment over the one-year period from July 2021 to June 2022.

test_cases.prompt: Question: How did the number of taxi drivers, private-hire car drivers, and delivery workers using online matching platforms in Singapore change from 2021 to 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: The number of taxi drivers, private-hire car drivers, and delivery workers using online matching platforms in Singapore increased from 25,400, 38,100, and 25,500 in 2021 to 25,500, 38,400, and 25,600 in 2022, respectively.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the distribution of full-time employed residents with gross monthly income from work (excluding employer CPF contributions) at or below $2,492 by industry in June 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: In June 2022, 19% of full-time employed residents with gross monthly income from work (excluding employer CPF contributions) at or below $2,492 were in the Transportation & Storage industry, 11% were in the Administrative & Support Services industry, and 11% were in the Food & Beverage Services industry.

test_cases.prompt: Question: How did the proportion of regular platform workers who faced challenges in their work change from 2021 to 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: The proportion of regular platform workers who faced challenges in their work declined from 58% in 2021 to 31% in 2022.

test_cases.prompt: Question: How does the employment rate of women in Singapore compare to that of men in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: The employment rate of women in Singapore in 2022 was 76.2%, which is higher than the employment rate of men (89.6%). The increased involvement of women in the workforce reflects their rising educational profile as well as efforts to promote more progressive gender attitudes and facilitative workplace practices.

test_cases.prompt: Question: How did the share of unemployed residents who left their last job due to relationship problems with colleagues/boss or disliked previous job/lack of interest change between 2020 and 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: According to the text, there was an increased share of unemployed residents who left their last job due to relationship problems with colleagues/boss or disliked previous job/lack of interest between 2020 and 2022.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the labour force participation rate for residents aged 15 and over in Singapore in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: The labour force participation rate for residents aged 15 and over in Singapore in 2022 was 70.0%, which is slightly lower than the high of 70.5% in 2021 but still higher than pre-COVID years.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the reason for the increase in the share of unemployed PMETs aged below 30 who left their last job due to low pay or lack of interest?
test_cases.expected_output: According to the text, the increase was due to an improvement in the share of unemployed PMETs aged below 30 who left their last job due to low pay or lack of interest.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the difference in work arrangements between regular own account workers and regular platform workers in Singapore in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: Regular platform workers in Singapore in 2022 had work arrangements that resembled those of employees, whereas regular own account workers were self-employed and had more autonomy in their work.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Which age group had the highest proportion of employees with a job tenure of at least 10 years?
test_cases.expected_output: The proportion of employees with a job tenure of at least 10 years was highest among those in their 30s and over. (Chart 42)

test_cases.prompt: Question: Why did the training intensity, measured as the average number of training days per adult in the labour force, fall slightly in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: The training intensity fell slightly in 2022 due to more time spent on easing back to the workplace as businesses resumed to pre-COVID normality, leaving less time for training.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the change in the proportion of self-employed workers in Singapore in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: The proportion of self-employed workers in Singapore declined in 2022, with a decrease in the share of own account workers, whose share of the resident workforce edged down for the second consecutive year following the high in 2020 at the height of the COVID-19 pandemic.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the employment rate for youths aged 15 to 24 in Singapore in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: The employment rate for youths aged 15 to 24 in Singapore in 2022 was 34.5%, which is lower than the previous year (37.2%) due to fewer students taking on part-time or temporary work.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the reason for the decrease in the proportion of full-time employed residents who worked from home in 2022 compared to 2021?
test_cases.expected_output: The decrease in the proportion of full-time employed residents who worked from home in 2022 compared to 2021 was due to the relaxation of pandemic-related restrictions.

test_cases.prompt: Question: How did the share of employed residents who had worked from home change in 2022 compared to a year ago?
test_cases.expected_output: The share of employed residents who had worked from home fell (34%) in 2022, compared to a year ago (49%) during the Heightened Alert phases. (5.1)

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the employment rate for seniors aged 65 and over in Singapore in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: The employment rate for seniors aged 65 and over in Singapore in 2022 was 31.0%, which is lower than the previous year (31.7%) but still higher than the average annual increase in the earlier period (+0.9%-points per year between 2012 and 2019).

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the trend in the proportion of fixed-term contract employees in Singapore in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: The proportion of fixed-term contract employees declined across most age, sex, and education groups in Singapore in 2022.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the employment rate for residents aged 25 to 64 in Singapore in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: The employment rate for residents aged 25 to 64 in Singapore in 2022 was 82.7%, which is higher than the previous year (81.8%) and a decade ago (78.8%).

test_cases.prompt: Question: Which industry had the highest proportion of workers who usually worked over 48 hours a week in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: Administrative & Support Services had the highest proportion of workers who usually worked over 48 hours a week in 2022.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Why did the relaxation of pandemic-related restrictions and the re-opening of borders benefit part-time workers in Singapore?
test_cases.expected_output: The relaxation of pandemic-related restrictions and the re-opening of borders allowed more part-time workers in consumer-facing and tourism-related sectors, such as Food & Beverage Services, Retail Trade, Accommodation, and Arts, Entertainment & Recreation, to work the number of hours they desired.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the annualized change in real* gross monthly income from work (including employer CPF contributions) of full-time employed residents in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: The annualized change in real* gross monthly income from work (including employer CPF contributions) of full-time employed residents in 2022 was 6.4%.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the employment rate for residents of Singapore aged 15 and over in 2022, and how does it compare to pre-COVID rates and OECD countries?
test_cases.expected_output: The employment rate for residents aged 15 and over in Singapore in 2022 was 67.5%, which is 2.3%-points above the pre-COVID rate in 2019.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the gross monthly income from work (including employer CPF contributions) of full-time employed residents in 2022, considering the impact of Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) payouts on the 20th percentile income level and the relaxation of pandemic restrictions that facilitated in-person business and social activities?
test_cases.expected_output: The gross monthly income from work (including employer CPF contributions) of full-time employed residents in 2022 was $4,446.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the reason for the increase in the share of non-PMETs who left their last job due to long working hours/demanding work in their previous employment, given the tight labor market and increased motivation for workers to seek new job opportunities?
test_cases.expected_output: According to the text, the increase was due to manpower shortages in sectors with returning consumer demand, which exacerbated the demand for workers in these sectors.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What factors led to the increase in training participation rate among plant and machine operators and assemblers, and how did it impact their job performance and career advancement?
test_cases.expected_output: The training participation rate among plant & machine operators & assemblers increased due to the lifting of COVID-19 restrictions, which enabled them to resume in-person training activities.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the proportion of Singaporean workers who changed jobs within the last two years in 2022, and how did it vary across different age groups and industries?
test_cases.expected_output: The proportion of employed residents who had changed jobs in the last two years rose to a six-year high of 17% in 2022. (Chart 38)

test_cases.prompt: Question: How did the proportion of workers who held multiple jobs in Singapore change from 2021 to 2022, given the challenges faced by regular own account workers and platform workers in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic?
test_cases.expected_output: The proportion of workers who held multiple jobs in Singapore declined from 2021 and remained low at 3%.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the percentage of employed residents in Singapore who were in permanent jobs in 2022, and how did it change compared to previous years?
test_cases.expected_output: According to Chart 14, the percentage of employed residents in Singapore who were in permanent jobs in 2022 was 86%.

test_cases.prompt: Question: How did the long-term unemployment rate for non-PMETs change between 2020 and 2022, given the industry-specific trends and reasons for involuntary unemployment during the pandemic recovery?
test_cases.expected_output: According to Chart 50, the long-term unemployment rate for non-PMETs decreased from 1.5% in 2020 to 1.1% in 2022.

test_cases.prompt: Question: How did the number of regular platform workers in Singapore change from 2021 to 2022, considering the challenges they faced during the COVID-19 pandemic?
test_cases.expected_output: The number of regular platform workers in Singapore increased from 73,200 in 2021 to 88,400 in 2022.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What caused the decline in involuntary unemployment among residents between 2020 and 2022, given that the unemployment rate among residents who left their jobs involuntarily decreased from 2.1% in 2020 to 0.8% in 2022, driven by a lower share of residents leaving their jobs due to retrenchment and temporary layoff without pay, which fell significantly over the year to pre-COVID levels, and there was an increase in the share of unemployed residents who left their last job due to low pay, relationship problems with colleagues/boss, or disliked previous job/lack of interest, and long working hours/demanding work in their previous employment also drove more non-PMETs to seek out other jobs, exacerbated by manpower shortages in sectors with returning consumer demand?
test_cases.expected_output: According to the text, the decline in involuntary unemployment among residents was attributed to a lower share of residents leaving their job due to retrenchment and temporary layoff without pay, which fell significantly over the year to pre-COVID levels.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What percentage of employed trainees recognized the importance of attending job-related structured training, and how did this recognition translate into tangible and intangible outcomes for their employment?
test_cases.expected_output: 92% of employed trainees recognized the importance of attending job-related structured training.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the resident time-related under-employment rate in Singapore in 2022, and how did it change compared to the previous year, particularly among different age, sex, and education groups, and how did the relaxation of pandemic-related restrictions and the re-opening of borders affect part-time workers in consumer-facing and tourism-related sectors?
test_cases.expected_output: The resident time-related under-employment rate in Singapore declined from 3.5% in 2021 to 3.0% in 2022, which is back to the pre-COVID range.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the primary cause of the decline in Singapore's self-employed population in 2022, particularly among those aged 60 and above?
test_cases.expected_output: The decrease in own account workers in Singapore in 2022 was largely due to a decline in the number of own account workers aged 60 and over.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the percentage of professionals, managers, executives, and technicians (PMETs) among employed residents in 2022, given that the share of graduates in higher-skilled and higher-paying professional, managerial, and executive (PME) roles increased from 78% in 2021 to 80% in 2022, which is the highest in over a decade?
test_cases.expected_output: According to Chart 14, the percentage of PMETs among employed residents in 2022 was 64%.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What factors contributed to the rise in training participation rate among unemployed residents from 14% in 2012 to 39% in 2022, and how did this impact the employability and job mobility of workers in Singapore?
test_cases.expected_output: The training participation rate of unemployed residents rose from 14% in 2012 to 39% in 2022.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What were the noticeable improvements in job search outcomes in Singapore in 2022, and how did they vary across different demographic groups?
test_cases.expected_output: Those who were more adversely affected by the pandemic, such as those in their 50s and older, those with non-tertiary qualifications, as well as service & sales workers and cleaners, labourers & related workers, saw improvements in job search outcomes in Singapore in 2022.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the likelihood of switching out of own account work for those who did own account work by choice in 2022, given the tight labor market and increased demand for transportation and delivery services?
test_cases.expected_output: The likelihood of switching out of own account work for those who did own account work by choice was higher in 2022 and 2021 when the labor market was comparatively tighter than earlier years.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What factors contributed to the decrease in multiple jobholding among workers in Singapore in 2022, amidst a sustained high training participation rate and changing training methods?
test_cases.expected_output: The decrease in multiple jobholding among workers in Singapore in 2022 was broad-based, but rose for workers in Food & Beverage Services, Arts, Entertainment & Recreation, and Other Community, Social & Personal Services.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Given the slight decrease in the labor force participation rate in 2022, what factors could have contributed to this decline despite the continued recovery of the resident labor force from the pandemic's impact?
test_cases.expected_output: The slight decrease in labour force participation rate in 2022 was due to the easing of demand for temporary pandemic-related roles, such as temperature screeners and safe distancing ambassadors, which presented opportunities for residents outside the labour force to take on short-term jobs.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the median income for full-time employed degree holders in Singapore in 2022, considering the impact of the tight labor market and the increased share of professionals, managers, executives, and technicians (PMETs) in the workforce?
test_cases.expected_output: According to Chart 11, the median income for full-time employed degree holders in Singapore in 2022 was $4,500.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the rate of employment among degree holders aged 25 to 64 in 2022, and how did it change over the longer term, given that the share of professionals, managers, executives, and technicians (PMETs) among employed residents increased to 64% in 2022, with a higher income for full-time employed degree holders, and a lower share of employees in non-permanent positions?
test_cases.expected_output: According to Chart 12, the employment rate among resident degree holders aged 25 to 64 in 2022 was 88.9%.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the proportion of residents aged 55 and over in the working-age population in 2022, and how did it change compared to the previous decade?
test_cases.expected_output: The share of residents aged 55 and over in the working-age population in 2022 was 36%.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What proportion of workers in Singapore had a job tenure of less than one year, given that the incidence of job change rose to a six-year high of 17% in 2022, with younger workers aged below 30 more likely to change jobs, and the share of employees with a tenure of less than one year remaining steady at around 18%?
test_cases.expected_output: The proportion of employees who took up their current job in the recent year held steady, with fewer workers entering the labour force compared to a year ago. (4.4)

test_cases.prompt: Question: Given that the number of regular own account workers in Singapore increased in 2022, what challenges did they face despite the growth, and how did their educational profile and age distribution change?
test_cases.expected_output: The number of regular own account workers in Singapore rose for the fourth consecutive year in 2022, but the rate of increase was smaller than the previous year.

test_cases.prompt: Question: How did the number of private-hire car drivers change in 2022 compared to 2020, considering the impact of the tightened labor market and increased demand for transportation services?
test_cases.expected_output: The number of private-hire car drivers increased in 2022 as demand for point-to-point transport services increased when more employees commuted to work. However, it was still below the number in 2020 (34,400) when weaker labor market conditions drew in more own account workers, including private-hire car drivers.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the percentage of young resident tertiary graduates who were in employment in 2022, and how did their employment rate and income compare to previous years and different education institutions?
test_cases.expected_output: According to Chart 12, the percentage of young resident tertiary graduates who were in employment in 2022 was 78%.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the reason for the increase in the share of unemployed residents who left their last job due to low pay amidst an economic recovery and tight labor market?
test_cases.expected_output: According to the text, the increase was due to a tighter labour market, which motivated workers who were dissatisfied with their work to quit and seek new job opportunities.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the rate of unemployment among PMETs in the 25-34 age group in 2022, and how did it compare to the long-term unemployment rate for this group in previous years?
test_cases.expected_output: According to Chart 49, the unemployment rate for PMETs in the 25-34 age group was 3.4% in 2022.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the training participation rate of resident labour force in Singapore in 2022, and how did it vary among different occupational groups and age groups?
test_cases.expected_output: The training participation rate of resident labour force in Singapore in 2022 was 39%.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the projected impact of an aging population on the overall labor force participation rate in the future, given the recent trend of increased employment rates among residents aged 25 to 64 and seniors aged 65 and over?
test_cases.expected_output: The labour force participation rate is likely to moderate in the future given the ageing population, as the increase in overall labour force participation will likely slow down.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What proportion of workers in Singapore participated in online training in 2022, and how did it change from previous years?
test_cases.expected_output: The proportion of structured training attendees who participated in online training in Singapore in 2022 was 58.4%.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the rate of employment for degree holders aged 25 to 64 in 2022, considering the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the labor market, particularly in sectors such as Information & Communication and Financial & Insurance Services, and how did it compare to pre-COVID years?
test_cases.expected_output: The employment rate of degree holders aged 25 to 64 in 2022 was 88.4%.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What factor led to the decline in average usual hours worked among full-time workers in 2022, despite the increase in job mobility and economic recovery?
test_cases.expected_output: The decline in average usual hours worked among full-timers was driven by the falling hours of full-timers who formed a large majority of employed residents. (5.1)

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the key findings and trends in the Labour Force in Singapore 2022 report, particularly regarding employment rates and labor force participation?
test_cases.expected_output: The main focus of the report is to provide a comprehensive review of the performance of the resident population in Singapore's labour market, with a focus on the continued recovery of the resident labour force from the impact of the pandemic and an assessment of patterns of improvement in relation to longer-term structural trends.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What factors contribute to the rising share of seniors in the resident labor force in Singapore, and how can their participation be further encouraged?
test_cases.expected_output: The share of females in the resident labour force in 2022 was 47%.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the labour force participation rate of residents aged 55 and over in 2022, and how did it change compared to previous years?
test_cases.expected_output: The labour force participation rate of residents aged 55 and over in 2022 was 51%.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the occupation with the lowest training rate in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: The training participation rate for non-PMETs (plant & machine operators & assemblers, cleaners, labourers & related workers) was lower than PMETs (managers & administrators, professionals, associate professionals & technicians) in 2022.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the median income for young, employed tertiary graduates in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: According to Chart 13, the median income for young resident tertiary graduates who were in employment in 2022 was $3,500.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What were the major hurdles for Singapore's self-employed in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: The top challenges faced by regular own account workers in Singapore in 2022 were healthcare-related concerns (18%) and uncertainty of finding sufficient work (16%).

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the long-term unemployment rate for Accommodation industry residents in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: According to Chart 54, the long-term unemployment rate for residents in the Accommodation industry was 0.4% in 2022.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the list of popular jobs in Singapore in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: Private-hire car drivers, taxi drivers, and delivery workers remained the top occupations of primary own account workers in Singapore in 2022.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What motivated Singapore's own account workers?
test_cases.expected_output: Most own account workers in Singapore did own account work as a main job by choice, as they prioritized flexibility and freedom associated with own account work, as well as having control over their career.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What occupation had the highest training rate in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: The tertiary educated had the highest training participation rate in 2022, forming the bulk of trainees (84%).

test_cases.prompt: Question: How did WIS impact 2022's 20th percentile income level?
test_cases.expected_output: The impact of Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) -related payouts on the 20th percentile income level was smaller in 2022 due to the strong growth in nominal income at the 20th percentile.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's behind the rise in longer-tenured employee share?
test_cases.expected_output: The increase in the share of longer-tenured employees was supported by skills and educational upgrading as well as policies such as the Retirement and Re-employment Act to keep older workers employable. (4.5)

test_cases.prompt: Question: What group had the most job changes in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: Younger workers aged below 30 had the highest incidence of job change, as they are more likely to explore different career options and gain more experience early in their working life. (Chart 39)

test_cases.prompt: Question: What were the top industries for residents aged 55+ in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: The top industries among employed residents aged 55 and over in 2022 were Land Transport & Supporting Services, and Food & Beverage Services.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the state of Singapore's unemployed residents' training participation rate over time?
test_cases.expected_output: The training participation rate of unemployed residents in Singapore has increased over time, from 14% in 2012 to 39% in 2022.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the proportion of workers with multiple jobs in SG in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: The proportion of workers who held multiple jobs in Singapore in 2022 was 3.1%.

test_cases.prompt: Question: How did platform-related incomes change from 2021 to 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: The median income of full-time platform-related occupations increased from $1,500 in 2021 to $2,000 in 2022.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the senior labour force share in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: The share of seniors in the resident labour force in 2022 was 27%.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the WIS impact on 2022's 20th percentile?
test_cases.expected_output: The impact of Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) payouts on the 20th percentile income level was smaller in 2022 due to the strong growth in nominal income at the 20th percentile.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What drove the 2022 income boost for private car drivers?
test_cases.expected_output: The increase in median income earned by private-hire car drivers in 2022 could be attributed to the increase in demand for point-to-point transport services as safe-distancing measures in society were gradually relaxed and removed.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What industries benefited from 2022's tourism comeback?
test_cases.expected_output: Accommodation and Arts, Entertainment & Recreation industries saw a surge in demand as tourism activities resumed in 2022.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the average training duration in SG?
test_cases.expected_output: The average trainee in Singapore received 5.4 days of training in 2022.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What industry had the highest unemployment rate in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: According to Chart 53, the industry with the highest unemployment rate among residents in 2022 was Wholesale Trade, with a rate of 0.6%.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was Singapore's 2022 worker estimate?
test_cases.expected_output: The estimate of regular own account workers in Singapore in 2022 was 202,700, which is 8.3% of all employed residents in 2022.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Where does Singapore stand in OECD employment rankings?
test_cases.expected_output: Singapore's employment rate ranks high among OECD countries, with a ranking of third place. Singapore ranks second for male employment rate and fourth for female employment rate.

test_cases.prompt: Question: How was 2022 for delivery workers?
test_cases.expected_output: The number of delivery workers continued to grow over the years and became the third most common occupation in 2022. Most of them did own account work as their main livelihood by choice.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the median income growth of full-time degree holders between 2017 and 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: The median income of full-time employed degree holders grew more slowly in real terms, at 0.6% per annum, from 2017 to 2022.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the resident labour force's training participation rate in Singapore in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: The training participation rate of resident labour force in Singapore in 2022 was almost one in two, or 49.5%.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the non-permanent employment rate among residents in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: According to Chart 15, the percentage of resident employees in non-permanent employment in 2022 was 10.5%.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the 411 on Singapore's platform workers in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: Regular platform workers in Singapore in 2022 were more likely to be older or lower-educated, with 62% aged 50 and over and 77% having non-tertiary qualifications.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What were the main reasons for non-trainees missing training in SG in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: The top reasons for non-trainees not attending training in Singapore in 2022 were work and family responsibilities, followed by a lack of perceived need for training and/or satisfaction with current skills and knowledge.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the production workforce percentage in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: According to Chart 14, the percentage of workers in production and related positions in 2022 was 36%.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the 2022 vs. 2021 P20 to P50 change?
test_cases.expected_output: The P20 to P50 income ratio increased from 0.53 in 2021 to 0.55 in 2022, the highest since 2004.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What factors contributed to the decline in the incidence of fixed-term contract employees across most age, sex, and education groups in Singapore in 2022, and how did this impact the overall employment landscape?
test_cases.expected_output: The decline in the incidence of fixed-term contract employees across most age, sex, and education groups in Singapore in 2022 was driven by a combination of factors. Firstly, the scale-back of pandemic-related contract jobs led to a more pronounced decline in the incidence of fixed-term contract employees in sectors that had earlier seen larger increases, such as Public Administration & Defence, Accommodation, Health & Social Services, and Real Estate Services. Secondly, the tight labour market in 2022 contributed to a decline in the incidence of fixed-term contract employees in growth sectors like Professional Services, Financial & Insurance Services, and Information & Communications. This decline was also driven by improvements in the educational profile of the workforce, which led to a higher share of professionals, managers, executives & technicians (PMETs) among employed residents. As a result, the proportion of fixed-term contract employees declined across most age, sex, and education groups. This shift towards more permanent employment arrangements had an impact on the overall employment landscape, as it reflected a more stable and secure job market. The tight labour market also contributed to a robust increase in median income for young resident tertiary graduates in employment, particularly for those in permanent jobs. Overall, the decline in fixed-term contract employees and the shift towards permanent employment arrangements suggest a strengthening of the job market in Singapore in 2022.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the proportion of fixed-term contract resident employees in Singapore in 2022, and how did it change from the previous year? Also, what was the reason for the change, and which groups saw the most notable improvements?
test_cases.expected_output: The proportion of fixed-term contract resident employees in Singapore declined across most age, sex, and education groups in 2022, with a significant decrease from 91,700 in June 2021 to 126,400 in June 2022. The relaxation of pandemic-related restrictions and the re-opening of borders led to more part-time workers in consumer-facing and tourism-related sectors such as Food & Beverage Services, Retail Trade, Accommodation, and Arts, Entertainment & Recreation being able to work the number of hours they desired, resulting in a decline in time-related underemployment rate from 3.5% in 2021 to 3.0% in 2022, with notable improvements among those who were more adversely affected by the pandemic, such as those in their 50s and older, those with non-tertiary qualifications, as well as among service & sales workers and cleaners, labourers & related workers. The fall in self-employment largely came from own account workers, whose share of the resident workforce edged down for the second consecutive year following the high in 2020 at the height of the COVID-19 pandemic, with a decrease led by workers aged 60 & over.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What specific factors contributed to the decline in the proportion of regular platform workers who faced challenges in their work in Singapore from 2021 to 2022, and how did these factors impact the top challenges faced by regular platform workers in 2022 differently from regular own account workers?
test_cases.expected_output: {'factors': ['decline in concerns related to business viability under COVID-related restrictions', 'increase in demand for point-to-point transport services', 'gradual relaxation and removal of safe-distancing measures in society'], 'impact': {'regular platform workers': ['similar top challenges as regular own account workers', 'increased concerns about retirement-related concerns and higher business expenses'], 'regular own account workers': ['eased back to pre-COVID levels', 'healthcare-related concerns and uncertainty of finding sufficient work']}}

test_cases.prompt: Question: What factors contributed to the narrowing of the income gap between the 20th percentile and the median income earners in 2022, despite the higher inflation rate, and how did this trend compare to the pre-pandemic years of 2014-2019?
test_cases.expected_output: The narrowing of the income gap between the 20th percentile and the median income earners in 2022 can be attributed to the tripartite initiatives such as the Progressive Wage Model, which supported lower-wage workers, and the strong growth in nominal income at the 20th percentile. This trend was observed despite the higher inflation rate in 2022 compared to the pre-pandemic years of 2014-2019. In fact, the real median income growth in 2022 was still lower than that in the years preceding the pandemic (2014-2019: 3.8% p.a.) when inflation was lower. However, the P20 income growth was consistently higher than that at the median for both periods, resulting in the gap between lower- and middle-income earners narrowing over the decade.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the percentage of regular own account workers who utilized online matching platforms in 2022, considering the rise in demand for point-to-point transport services and the increase in the number of delivery workers, and how does this percentage compare to the previous year?
test_cases.expected_output: In 2022, 38% of regular own account workers utilized online matching platforms, which is an increase from 33% in 2021. This increase is likely due to the rise in demand for point-to-point transport services and the growth in the number of delivery workers, which has created more opportunities for own account workers in these occupations to find work through online platforms.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the impact of the relaxation of pandemic restrictions on the distribution of full-time employed residents with gross monthly income from work (excluding employer CPF contributions) at or below $2,492 by industry in 2022, and how did this affect the long-term unemployment rate for non-PMETs in the same year?
test_cases.expected_output: The relaxation of pandemic restrictions in 2022 led to a surge in demand for ride-hailing services and dining-out frequency, which increased revenues for self-employed workers in the Transportation & Storage and Food & Beverage Services industries. This resulted in a decline in the share of lower-wage workers in self-employment, from 25% in 2021 to 18% in 2022. As a result, the long-term unemployment rate for non-PMETs in 2022 was 0.7%, a decline from the previous year. Additionally, the distribution of full-time employed residents with gross monthly income from work (excluding employer CPF contributions) at or below $2,492 by industry in 2022 was: Transportation & Storage (15%), Administrative & Support Services (11%), and Food & Beverage Services (11%).

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the impact of the relaxation of pandemic-related restrictions on the proportion of full-time employed residents who usually worked over 48 hours a week in 2022, and how did this trend compare to the pre-COVID years of 2014-2019?
test_cases.expected_output: The proportion of full-time employed residents who usually worked over 48 hours a week decreased in 2022, continuing a downward trend that started in 2010. The decrease was observed across most industries, but there were upticks in Administrative & Support Services, as well as tourism-related Accommodation, Arts, Entertainment & Recreation, and Food & Beverage Services. This trend was likely influenced by the relaxation of pandemic-related restrictions, which led to an increase in business activities and demand for labor in these industries. However, the proportion of full-time employed residents working long hours remained lower than pre-COVID levels (2014-2019: 3.8% p.a.), indicating a shift towards shorter working hours and better work-life balance.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What percentage of employed trainees reported gaining new job-related skills as a tangible outcome of training, and how does this compare to the percentage who received a pay raise or promotion? How does this outcome rank among the top digital skills taken up by employed trainees, and what does this suggest about the importance of training for career advancement?
test_cases.expected_output: According to Chart 36, 42% of employed trainees reported gaining new job-related skills as a tangible outcome of training. This is lower than the percentage who received a pay raise (5.5%) or promotion (2.7%). However, it ranks among the top digital skills taken up by employed trainees, with data analytics being the skillset most respondents are interested in learning. This suggests that training is important for career advancement and enhances work productivity.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the impact of the increased job mobility and tenure observed in 2022 on the average weekly usual hours worked among employed residents?
test_cases.expected_output: The increase in job mobility and tenure observed in 2022, particularly among younger workers and in growth sectors, may have contributed to the continued decline in the average weekly usual hours worked among employed residents. As workers change jobs, they may negotiate for better work-life balance or flexible work arrangements, leading to a decrease in average weekly hours worked. Additionally, the increase in longer-tenured employees may indicate a greater sense of job security, which could lead to a decrease in the average weekly hours worked as employees may feel more comfortable taking time off or working fewer hours without fear of losing their job.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What factors contributed to the shift towards digitally intermediated work and higher demand for transport and delivery services among primary own account workers in Singapore in 2022, and how did this impact the educational profile of primary own account workers?
test_cases.expected_output: The shift towards digitally intermediated work and higher demand for transport and delivery services among primary own account workers in Singapore in 2022 can be attributed to various factors, including the rise of online matching platforms and the increasing demand for point-to-point transport services. This shift led to a higher share of tertiary educated among primary own account workers, as workers with higher levels of education were more likely to take up work via online matching platforms and have the necessary skills to adapt to the changing job market. Additionally, the trend towards digitally intermediated work and higher demand for transport and delivery services also led to an increase in the number of private-hire car drivers and delivery workers, who made up the top occupations among primary own account workers in 2022. As a result, the educational profile of primary own account workers shifted towards a higher proportion of tertiary educated workers.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the median income of full-time employed degree holders in 2022, considering the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the labor market, the increase in female and senior labor force participation rates, and the shift towards higher-skilled and higher-paying professional, managerial, and executive roles?
test_cases.expected_output: $8,190, which resumed the upward trend observed in pre-COVID years, driven by the increased share of graduates in higher-skilled and higher-paying professional, managerial, and executive roles, which grew more slowly in real terms at 0.6% per annum from 2017 to 2022, despite the firm and rising demand for manpower from outward-oriented sectors such as Information & Communication and Financial & Insurance Services, as well as Health & Social Services, sectors which were less impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, resulting in a two-decade high employment rate of 88.4% for degree holders aged 25 to 64 in 2022, and an increasing share of degree graduates in the labor force, particularly those with degree qualifications, which rose from 29% in 2012 to 42% in 2022, with the share of seniors in the labor force continuing to rise, and the prevalence of part-time employment and self-employment in certain sectors attracting seniors who prefer greater autonomy over their work schedule, and the overall labor force participation rate moderating given the ageing population.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What were the industries that saw a rise in demand for jobs in 2022 due to the relaxation of pandemic restrictions, and how did this impact the unemployment rate among lower-wage workers in the same year?
test_cases.expected_output: The industries that saw a rise in demand for jobs in 2022 due to the relaxation of pandemic restrictions were Transportation & Storage, and Food & Beverage Services. This led to a decrease in the share of lower-wage workers in self-employment, from 25% in 2021 to 18% in 2022, and a surge in demand for ride-hailing services and dining-out frequency, which increased revenues for the self-employed. However, the unemployment rate among lower-wage workers remained steady at 4.4%, as the increased demand for jobs in these industries did not lead to a significant increase in unemployment among this group.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What specific factors contributed to the challenges faced by regular own account workers in 2022, and how did they vary from pre-COVID years?
test_cases.expected_output: The challenges faced by regular own account workers in 2022 were influenced by several factors, including the rise of digitally enabled business models, changes in the labor market, and demographic shifts. The share of own account workers who faced challenges has eased back to levels seen pre-COVID, but healthcare and job uncertainty remained top concerns. The likelihood of switching out of own account work for those who did own account work by choice was higher in 2022 and 2021 when the labor market was comparatively tighter than earlier years, suggesting that notwithstanding the motivations for own account work, a higher share would move to full-time employee jobs if there were opportunities to do so. Moreover, private-hire car drivers, taxi drivers, and delivery workers remained the top occupations of primary own account workers, reflecting the underlying trend toward more digitally intermediated work and higher demand for transport and delivery services. Seniors made up one in two primary own account workers in 2022, and the educational profile of primary own account workers showed a gradual increase in the share of tertiary educated, in line with the trend for the general workforce.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What were the factors that contributed to the decline in the incidence of fixed-term contract employees in growth sectors like Professional Services, Financial & Insurance Services, and Information & Communications in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: The decline in the incidence of fixed-term contract employees in growth sectors in 2022 was driven by a combination of factors. Firstly, the tight labour market led to a shift towards permanent employment, as seen in the increase in the proportion of permanent employees to 86% for degree holders from local autonomous universities. Additionally, the scale-back of pandemic-related contract jobs in sectors such as Public Administration & Defence, Accommodation, Health & Social Services, and Real Estate Services also contributed to the decline. Furthermore, the ongoing upward trajectory of the PMET share in the resident workforce, supported by robust manpower demand in outward-oriented sectors, also played a role in the decline of fixed-term contract employees in growth sectors.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the unemployment rate for PMETs in 2022, considering the impact of Workfare Income Supplement (WIS) payouts, the rise in the qualifying monthly income cap for WIS, the distribution of full-time employed residents with gross monthly income from work (excluding employer CPF contributions) at or below $2,492 by industry, the share of lower-wage workers in self-employment, the relaxation of pandemic restrictions, the surge in dining-out frequency, the increase in revenues for the self-employed, and the need for reskilling and upskilling among older workers or those with secondary or lower qualifications?
test_cases.expected_output: The unemployment rate for PMETs in 2022 was 2.6%, taking into account the factors mentioned above, which indicate a strong growth in nominal income at the 20th percentile, a smaller impact of WIS-related payouts on the 20th percentile income level, a decline in the share of lower-wage workers in self-employment, and a need for reskilling and upskilling among older workers or those with secondary or lower qualifications, resulting in an improvement in unemployment rates for both PMETs and non-PMETs, with most age groups seeing their unemployment rates fall back to pre-COVID levels, and a steady long-term unemployment rate for PMETs and non-PMETs, indicating better job search outcomes in 2022.

test_cases.prompt: Question: How does the shift in training participation rates among different age groups and labor force status in Singapore reflect the changing attitudes towards lifelong learning and employability in the post-pandemic era?
test_cases.expected_output: According to Charts 30-33 in the given context, there has been a slight decrease in training participation rates among workers in Singapore, particularly among younger workers below the age of 40. However, mature workers have continued to prioritize training to remain relevant in the dynamic employment landscape. This suggests that there is a growing recognition of the importance of lifelong learning and upskilling, especially among older workers who may be looking to switch careers or adapt to changing job demands. Additionally, the fact that training participation rates have remained steady among the unemployed suggests that jobseekers recognize the value of training in enhancing their employability in a competitive job market. Overall, the shifts in training participation rates reflect a changing attitude towards lifelong learning and employability in Singapore, where workers are proactively investing in their skills and knowledge to stay relevant and competitive in the post-pandemic era.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What specific factors contributed to the shift towards online training in Singapore during the pandemic, and how did it affect the training participation rate among different age groups and labor force status?
test_cases.expected_output: {'factors': ['increased availability of online training platforms and resources', 'reduced time spent on training due to work and family responsibilities', 'recognition of the need for lifelong learning and upskilling', 'shift towards more flexible and self-directed learning methods'], 'effects': [{'age group': 'younger workers aged below 40', 'change': 'decrease in training participation rate'}, {'age group': 'mature workers', 'change': 'increase in training participation rate'}, {'labor force status': 'unemployed residents', 'change': 'increase in training participation rate'}]}

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the factors that contributed to the increase in training participation rate among unemployed residents, and how did it impact their employability?
test_cases.expected_output: {'parts': [{'text': 'The training participation rate of unemployed residents rose from 14% in 2012 to 39% in 2022, with the bulk of trainees being tertiary educated.', 'reference': '3.7, 3.8, 3.9'}, {'text': 'The training participation rate increased for plant & machine operators & assemblers, cleaners, labourers & related workers, and rebounded strongly for plant & machine operators & assemblers due to the lifting of COVID-19 restrictions.', 'reference': '3.8'}, {'text': 'The training participation rate also increased in sectors with higher concentrations of non-PMETs, such as Transportation & Storage and Administrative & Support Services.', 'reference': '3.8'}, {'text': 'Among PMET occupational groups, the training participation rate for managers & administrators rose, but declined for professionals and associate professionals & technicians.', 'reference': '3.9'}, {'text': 'Most employed trainees (92%) recognized the importance of attending job-related structured training, and more than half of employed trainees experienced at least one tangible outcome after attending training, such as being more productive on the job, having the ability to provide better service delivery, or gaining new job-related skills.', 'reference': '3.10'}, {'text': 'Training also enhanced the employability of workers, with 12% stating that training has helped them retain their existing job or obtain a new job, and 19% were accorded new or additional job responsibilities following training.', 'reference': '3.11'}, {'text': 'The proportion who received a pay raise (5.5%) or promotion (2.7%) were lower as these outcomes were usually also tied to work performance.', 'reference': '3.11'}, {'text': 'With the increasing use of technology to harness data for informed decision making in organisations, data analytics (27%) and computer literacy skills (22%) were the top digital skills taken up by employed trainees.', 'reference': '3.12'}]}

test_cases.prompt: Question: What factors contributed to the increase in the share of degree graduates in the labor force, and how did this impact the employment rate and median income of full-time employed degree holders in 2022?
test_cases.expected_output: The increase in the share of degree graduates in the labor force can be attributed to a rise in the labor force participation rate of residents aged 15 and over, particularly among females and seniors. Additionally, the share of seniors in the labor force continued to rise, with a large increase in their labor force participation rate. This led to an increase in the employment rate of degree holders aged 25 to 64, with a firm and rising demand for manpower from sectors such as Information & Communication and Financial & Insurance Services. As a result, the median income of full-time employed degree holders rose to $8,190 in 2022, driven by the increased share of graduates in higher-skilled and higher-paying professional, managerial, and executive roles.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the primary factor that contributed to the decrease in the unemployment rate among non-PMETs in their 30s in 2022, despite an increase in their unemployment rate due to more people leaving their jobs to take care of their families and unmet expectations at work, given that the relaxation of pandemic restrictions facilitated in-person business and social activities, including heightened demand for ride-hailing services and a surge in dining-out frequency, which increased revenues for the self-employed, and the fact that lower-wage workers, proxied by full-time employed residents earning less than or equal to the 20th percentile gross monthly income, were commonly employed in industries such as Transportation & Storage, Administrative & Support Services, and Food & Beverage Services, and more than half of them were older workers aged 50 and over or those with secondary or lower qualifications, highlighting the need for reskilling and upskilling to remain relevant and adaptable to the current needs of the labor market?
test_cases.expected_output: The primary factor that contributed to the decrease in the unemployment rate among non-PMETs in their 30s in 2022 was the improvement in the long-term unemployment rate, which remained steady over the year at 0.3%, indicating that they did not face increased difficulties in securing employment, despite an increase in their unemployment rate due to more people leaving their jobs to take care of their families and unmet expectations at work. This was likely due to the fact that the relaxation of pandemic restrictions facilitated in-person business and social activities, including heightened demand for ride-hailing services and a surge in dining-out frequency, which increased revenues for the self-employed, and the fact that lower-wage workers, proxied by full-time employed residents earning less than or equal to the 20th percentile gross monthly income, were commonly employed in industries such as Transportation & Storage, Administrative & Support Services, and Food & Beverage Services, and more than half of them were older workers aged 50 and over or those with secondary or lower qualifications, highlighting the need for reskilling and upskilling to remain relevant and adaptable to the current needs of the labor market.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What digital skill did employed trainees mostly take up, and how did it relate to their career advancement and work productivity, and what was the reason behind the choice of this digital skill, and how did it align with the trend of technology adoption in organizations?
test_cases.expected_output: Employed trainees mostly took up data analytics (27%) as their top digital skill, which aligns with the trend of technology adoption in organizations that use data for informed decision-making. This skill enhances work productivity (60%) and aids career advancement (38%), as it helps workers to be more productive on the job, provide better service delivery, gain new job-related skills, and potentially benefit from higher pay or promotion. The choice of this digital skill was influenced by the increasing use of technology to harness data in organizations, and it aligns with the plans of most residents in the labor force who intend to attend structured training next year to pick up digital technology skills, with data analytics being the skillset most respondents are interested in learning.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the impact of the pandemic on the income growth of lower-wage workers in Singapore in 2022, and how did it compare to the pre-COVID years of 2014-2019?
test_cases.expected_output: Lower-wage workers in Singapore saw stronger income growth in 2022 compared to the median worker, supported by tripartite initiatives such as the Progressive Wage Model. Real income at the 20th percentile grew at a steady pace of 4.7% in 2022, faster than the previous year (4.4%) as well as the pre-COVID years (2014-2019: 4.4% p.a.). As a result, the gap between the P20 and P50 incomes has narrowed. However, over the longer term of 2017 to 2022, real P20 and P50 incomes grew slower than the preceding five years of 2012 to 2017, weighed down by the effects of the pandemic. Nonetheless, P20 income growth was consistently higher than that at the median for both periods, indicating that the gap between lower- and middle-income earners has been narrowing over the decade.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What was the impact of the pandemic and government initiatives on the income growth of lower-wage workers in Singapore in 2022, and how did it compare to the pre-COVID years of 2014-2019?
test_cases.expected_output: Lower-wage workers in Singapore saw stronger income growth in 2022 compared to the median worker, supported by tripartite initiatives such as the Progressive Wage Model. Real income at the 20th percentile grew at a steady pace of 4.7% in 2022, faster than the previous year (4.4%) and the pre-COVID years (2014-2019: 4.4% p.a.). As a result, the gap between the P20 and P50 incomes has narrowed. However, over the longer term of 2017 to 2022, real P20 and P50 incomes grew slower than the preceding five years of 2012 to 2017, weighed down by the effects of the pandemic. Nonetheless, P20 income growth was consistently higher than that at the median for both periods, indicating that the gap between lower- and middle-income earners has been narrowing over the decade.
